scenario:
ExxonMobil (XOM) is considered a reliable dividend payer with a 3.6% forward-yielding dividend. The company has maintained a streak of hiking its dividend for 42 consecutive years and has a track record of generating consistent free cash flow per share in excess of the dividend payments. ExxonMobil expects steady growth over the next six years, with earnings and operating cash flow projected to rise at compound annual growth rates of 10% and 8%, respectively. The company's extensive operations up and down the energy value chain make it a leading oil dividend stock.

Illinois Tool Works (ITW) is a highly diversified company with high operating margins and a strong track record of dividend increases, with 53 consecutive years of dividend hikes. The company's diversification and high margins make it well-positioned to absorb a slowdown in certain segments. ITW has a 2.3% yield and a 24.1 forward price-to-earnings ratio, making it a premium-priced stock but one worth considering for its dividend quality.

The JPMorgan Equity Premium Income ETF (JEPI) is a high-yield ETF that currently yields 7.3% and invests at least 80% of its assets in equities. However, its primary method of generating income comes from investing up to 20% of its assets in equity-linked notes (ELNs) that sell monthly call options linked to the S&P 500 index. This strategy allows the ETF to pick up premiums from the ELN strategy during a market sell-off, making it a relatively safe way to generate passive income.
